title: About me
text: Growing up in the Pacific Northwest, I was immersed in nature from an early age. In turn, outside of being a statistics, data science, and forestry educator and researcher, many of my passions relate to spending time outdoors. Some of my hobbies include exploring new places with my dog (“Dude”, pictured below), cycling, camping, and trying my best to perfect my home espresso skills and technique.

title: Research
text: My research interests lie in small area estimation, hierarchical Bayesian modeling, survey statistics, statistical software, and computing. I am broadly interested in statistical problems motivated by applications to forestry and forest inventory and in answering authentically-motivated research questions from the USDA Forest Service. Central themes in my research include developing novel estimation methods for environmental data and developing simulation-based techniques for the formal evaluation of statistical estimators. I strive to increase practical impact of my research via the development of statistical software such as R packages and interactive dashboards.

title: Research
text:
Preprints

White G.W., Finley A.O., Yamamoto J.K., Green J.L., Frescino T.S., MacFarlane D.W., and Andersen H.E. (2025+) Hierarchical models for small area estimation using zero-inflated forest inventory variables: comparison and implementation. arXiv preprint. https://arxiv.org/abs/2503.22103

Emick E., Babcock C., White G.W., Hudak A.T., Domke G.M., and Finley A.O. (2023) An approach to estimating forest biomass while quantifying estimate uncertainty and correcting bias in machine learning maps. Remote Sensing of Environment. 295, 113678, https://doi.org/10.1016/j.rse.2023.113678
Frescino T.S., Moisen G.G., Patterson P.L., Toney J.C., and White G.W. (2023) FIESTA: a forest inventory estimation and analysis R package. Ecography. 7, e06428, https://doi.org/10.1111/ecog.06428
Frescino T.S., McConville K.S., White G.W., Toney, J.C., and Moisen G.G. (2022) Small Area Estimates for National Applications: A Database to Dashboard Strategy Using FIESTA. Frontiers in Forests and Global Change. 5, 107, https://doi.org/10.3389/ffgc.2022.779446
White G.W., McConville K.S., Moisen G.G., and Frescino T.S. (2021) Hierarchical Bayesian Small Area Estimation Using Weakly Informative Priors in Ecologically Homogeneous Areas of the Interior Western Forests. Frontiers in Forests and Global Change. 4, 178, https://doi.org/10.3389/ffgc.2021.752911

title: Research
text:

Josh K. Yamamoto, Dinan Elsyad D, Grayson W. White, Julian Schmitt, Niels Korsgaard, Kelly S. McConville, and Jie Kate Hu (2024). saeczi: Small Area Estimation for Continuous Zero Inflated Data. R package version 0.2.0. https://CRAN.R-project.org/package=saeczi
Tracey S. Frescino, Gretchen G. Moisen, Paul L. Patterson, J. Chris Toney, and Grayson W. White (2022). FIESTA: A forest inventory estimation and analysis R package. R package version 3.6.4. https://cran.r-project.org/package=FIESTA
Grayson W. White (2020). gglm: Grammar of Graphics for Linear Model Diagnostics. R package version 1.0.2. https://CRAN.R-project.org/package=gglm

title: Teaching
text: As an educator I aim to create an inclusive, safe, welcoming, and productive space for students to engage deeply with statistics and data science concepts. I strive to help students gain confidence in their mathematical, statistical, and programmatic skills by making my courses feel accessible and welcoming, genuinely engaging with questions and feedback from students, and adapting my practices based on continued experience in the classroom.

title: Teaching
text:

Instructor, Math 141: Introduction to Probability and Statistics (Fall 2025)

Teaching Assistant, Forestry 128: Practical Computing and Data Science Tools (Spring 2023)

title: Teaching
text:
Other experience
Prior to my time in academia, I was a Data Science Educator at Posit. Further, as an undergraduate at Reed College I was a Course Assistant and Tutor for Math 141: Introduction to Probability and Statistics, Math 241: Data Science, Math 392: Mathematical Statistics, and Econ 311: Survey of Econometric Methods.

title: Grayson White
text:
I am a Visiting Assistant Professor of Statistics at Reed College.
My research interests are in small area estimation, hierarchical Bayesian modeling, environmental statistics applied to forestry and natural resources problems, and statistical software development. More specifically, my research focuses on implementing model-based statistical methods for small area estimation of forest attributes, and developing methodologies for formal assessment of those estimators.
I have a passion for teaching data science and statistics, and for mentoring undergraduate students on research projects. I have had the great pleasure of co-directing and mentoring students in the Undergraduate Forestry Data Science Lab during summers at Harvard University and at Bucknell University. Further, I wholeheartedly believe in the benefits and impact of statistical software for teaching, learning, and research. I’ve developed R packages for teaching statistics, as a result of research with undergraduates and for implementing methodological research. I also maintain an R package with my collaborators from the U.S. Forest Service, FIESTA, which is used for both internally and externally for forest inventory estimation projects and research.
